docs.lead_paragraph: A 19-year-old Brooklyn woman gave birth to a boy late Friday night, then promptly dropped it into shrubbery outside her first-floor window, the police said yesterday. The baby, who was only slightly injured in the fall, was listed in stable condition yesterday at Interfaith Medical Center, the police said. They said the baby's mother, Melissa Olivencia, faces charges of endangering the welfare of a child, attempted assault and attempted murder.

headline.main: Woman Dropped Baby Out Window, Police Say

docs.abstract: New York City police say 19-year-old woman gave birth to boy and then dropped infant into shrubbery outside her first-floor window; baby is only slightly injured; Melissa Olivencia is charged with attempted murder (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Both considered themselves moderate Republicans and both were faced with the tough issue of abortion. One made a stand on principle and will be remembered as a man of courage and integrity. The other has carefully gauged the direction of the wind, and may well end up as President. The early-1970's was still a treacherous time for women or girls who wanted to terminate a pregnancy. Thousands of women, particularly those who were well educated and well off financially, were able to get legal abortions through physicians willing to engage in some charade, like claiming the mother's life was in danger. Some wealthy women could get illegal abortions that were reasonably safe, or go overseas for abortions. But the vast majority of women and girls who wanted an abortion had no alternative but to roll the dice on a criminal procedure that might be performed in some wretched undercover location by some inept practitioner using unsanitary and often unscientific methods.
docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column recalls treacherous time for women needing abortions in past years; pays tribute to late Justice Harry Blackmun, who will be remembered as man of courage and integrity for making stand on principle; contrasts him with George W Bush, who carefully equivocates and may well end up as President (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: There are a baseball and a bat etched onto Michael Juman's headstone. ''Cherished son and brother,'' the epitaph reads, ''Jan. 5, 1965 to Mar. 11, 1994.'' Michael's father, Martin Juman, braces against a brisk wind as he walks through the Wellwood Cemetery on Long Island to visit his son. ''He's waiting for answers,'' Martin says, looking at the grave. ''We promised him we'd find them.'' While Michael lived, particularly during his final years, his life was filled mostly with questions. Who was the woman who gave birth to him? Could she tell him anything about the demons that occupied his brain? Was there something in his genetic past that could explain the bugs that crawled around him -- insects only he could see? Or the keening bursts of rage that so frightened his parents? Or the frenzied fits that led him to pull clumps of hair from his own head?

headline.main: What the Jumans Didn't Know About Michael

docs.abstract: Lisa Belkin article on adoption of Michael Juman, who committed suicide in 1994 after struggle with mental illness; notes adoption agency knowingly concealed from Jumans, who adopted Michael as infant, his genetic legacy of schizophrenia at time when disease was considered largely result of environment; recalls Michael's search for information about birth mother and his insistence that family sue agency for wrongful adoption; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: In this bucolic slice of southeastern Virginia, sturdy farmhouses command vast fields of peanuts, soybeans and cotton. Slender loblolly pines poke through the flat, wet terrain, like celery stalks wedged into a marshy bog. It seems like a Robert Penn Warren poem sprung to life. But if this county is rich in beauty, it is also poor in opportunities. For years, the courthouse had no indoor plumbing, and so little space that defendants occasionally had to wait outside before their arraignments. No new schools have been built in 30 years, and teachers had to make do with antiquated equipment.

headline.main: Luster of New York's Trash Dims in Virginia

docs.abstract: Sussex County, Va, in 1994 embarked on controversial path that many people believed would improve their struggling economy, even though it would jeopardize their beloved environs: private, technologically advanced landfill that would import thousands of tons of garbage a day, much of it from New York City; landfill generates one-third of all annual local revenues--over $12.3 million so far in taxes and fees; county has found itself in middle of multistate battle over trash; issue has become hot topic, with politicians deploring Virginia's status as second-biggest importer of out-of-state trash, after Pennsylvania; Virginia General Assembly has approved legislation limiting garbage imports; Sens Charles S Robb and John W Warner are sponsoring bill that would also restrict flow of garbage; most Virginians support moves, but in Sussex, reaction has been more ambivalent; map; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In your March 8 front-page article ''Mothers on Medicaid Overcharged for Pain Relief,'' an anesthesiologist, perhaps taking a cue from Marie Antoinette, compares pain relief in childbirth to the privilege of driving a Rolls-Royce, since both are expensive. While Federal reimbursement rates may not always be fair or rational, surely physicians have other recourse than to extort money from patients in labor.

headline.main: You're in Labor: Get Out Your Wallet

docs.abstract: Paula B Doress-Worters letter deplores March 8 report that some anesthesiologists in Florida and California are requiring upfront payments from Medicaid patients in active labor before performing epidurals

headline.main: You're in Labor: Get Out Your Wallet; Doctors Break a Law

docs.lead_paragraph: Many women trying to become pregnant are careful to avoid ingesting any substance that might impair their fertility or damage a developing embryo. According to a new study, several popular herbal remedies should be added to the list of substances that could have detrimental effects on men as well as women and could interfere with conception or a healthy pregnancy. Despite the widespread belief, often fostered by advertising copy, that herbal preparations are ''natural'' and ''drug-free,'' those that have druglike effects in the body do in fact contain potent chemicals that act like drugs.

headline.main: Herbal Remedies Tied to Pregnancy Risks

docs.abstract: New study finds several popular herbal remedies might intefere with conception or healthy pregnancy; researchers found St John's wort, Echinacea purpura and Ginkgo biloba had ill effects on either eggs or sperm or both; findings published in current issue of Fertility and Sterility, journal (M)
docs.snippet: Many women trying to become pregnant are careful to avoid ingesting any substance that might impair their fertility or damage a developing embryo. According to a new study, several popular herbal remedies should be added to the list of substances...

docs.lead_paragraph: Many children as young as 10 years old want to know more about sex than just where babies come from, but parents often shy away from discussing sexuality, according to a national survey conducted by the Kaiser Family Foundation and Children Now, a children's advocacy group. Topics that may have parents blushing even in discussions with teen-agers have filtered down to children ages 10 to 12. In a random-sample telephone survey of 161 children in that age group and 447 parents, more than 40 percent of the children said they wanted to know how to handle peer pressure, how to know when they were ready for sexual activity and how alcohol and drugs might affect their decisions.

headline.main: Getting Beyond the Birds and the Bees

docs.abstract: National survey conducted by Kaiser Family Foundation and Children Now finds parents often shy away from discussing sexuality with their children, other than having simple 'birds and bees' talk; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Many children as young as 10 years old want to know more about sex than just where babies come from, but parents often shy away from discussing sexuality, according to a national survey conducted by the Kaiser Family Foundation and Children Now, a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Some doctors and hospitals have been forcing poor women to pay hundreds of dollars in cash for a popular procedure to relieve pain in childbirth, Federal officials say, and the Government has ordered hospitals to stop demanding such cash payments. Federal law says pregnant Medicaid patients may not be charged for prenatal care, delivery or other medical services that relate to pregnancy. Medicaid reimburses hospitals and doctors for such services, but doctors say the payments for pain treatment are grossly inadequate, sometimes only 10 percent or 20 percent of what private insurance companies pay.

headline.main: Mothers on Medicaid Overcharged for Pain Relief

docs.abstract: Medicaid director Sally K Richardson orders doctors and hospitals to stop improperly demanding cash payments from poor women covered by Medicaid for covered services, especially use of epidural block to relieve pain in childbirth, letter to state health officials; doctors say Medicaid payments for epidural are grossly inadequate; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Some doctors and hospitals have been forcing poor women to pay hundreds of dollars in cash for a popular procedure to relieve pain in childbirth, Federal officials say, and the Government has ordered hospitals to stop demanding such cash payments.   ...
